mnemonic: This radical looks a little like the letter P, right? It's a P printed onto something... wait, it's not printed, it's a stamp that's been put on the paper. Peter Parker likes to use stamps instead of pens.

The radical ground and big make up this radical. There's a big guy on the ground... who is that big guy? Embarrassingly, it's your husband. Feel the shame that he got knocked down on the ground. By what? Who? How? (It doesn't matter.)

This looks like a little tamagotchi or (if you aren't a 90s kid) a duck. What do both of these critters have in common? They have really crazy clan followings. And the people who enjoy them (tiny pocket games or watching quacking duckies) create clans that get together and share their experiences. Which clan are you a part of?

Your mama is carrying some kind of elaborate weapon. You look closely and see that it's a spear. The pointy end is to the right, and there are some decorations hanging off it. It's a very fancy spear, and you wonder where your mama got it.
This looks like a boat coming toward you in the water. See the billowing sail and the reflection off the water? That's what boats look like
In a prison on a rice paddy they're boiling something. What do you think it is? Fish! What goes better with rice? What's easy to find, making it cheap prison food? Fish, of course!
See the cool wing on the bottom? See the head with the neat feather coming out of the top? This is a bird. Tweet tweet!

Flowers that grow out of the ground of a rice paddy after you bury fins there will grow yellow. Why? Because yellow is the color of a fish's soul, so planting flowers over their fins will turn them into a nice, pretty yellow.

If you boil a village everything will turn black. Mostly because you're a crazed murderer, but more so because when you boil a village all the roads melt and coat everything in black tar. Picture it! It looks like Pompeii. (Oof, too soon?)

Put some dirt around your head and in your mouth to figure out your head's circumference. When you pull your head out you'll have the perfect shape of your head, making measuring the circumference easy. Oh, and the dirt in your mouth? That's just for the taste.
See the wing? It's kind of like a bat wing with webbing. Either way, it's just a wing.
What happens when you put a flat surface on top of a pair of legs? You get a table.

This radical looks kind of like a temple on a hill, don't you think? With all the layers, n' stuff? Just picture that first horizontal line as the base of the ornate temple balancing on that hill underneath it and you'll have no problem remembering this radical.
This radical already looks like a gate, right? Just imagine a big gate with two pillars, one on either side. Then, up above are the doors, which can come down at any moment.

This looks a bit like a backwards S. S for Self. But it's backwards because you didn't want to mix yourself up with any of the other selves out there, so you flipped it. That's why it means oneself. (That's you!)
This radical will appear as things like yourself, herself, etc., so keep that in mind!

You have the animal radical in this already, that should be a clue. What kind of animal is it? It's in the ground, covered in mud. Also, there are toes laying around with it, because this animal will eat anything (good way to get rid of bodies... I hear). So what's this animal that's covered in mud and eats toes because it will eat anything? It's a pig!

This radical is made up of coffin and child. To keep a child out of a coffin they'll need a good teacher to make sure they know not to stick forks in outlets or dance in traffic. That's why this radical is a teacher.
This radical looks just like a top hat. That's why it's top hat!
This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. Lack becomes Lack!
on-yomi-mnemonic: You're lacking something in your fridge. You look around, trying to find the ketsup (けつ) you lack. You can't find it, because you lack it.

mnemonic: Your clan is where you get your name. But not your given name, your family name.
on-yomi-mnemonic: Don't worry, I'll tell you where your family name came from. Your family used to herd sheep (し). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day.

mnemonic: A giant cross with a mouth stands above you. "I am reason!" it says to you. It is the Cross of Reason.
on-yomi-mnemonic: The reason that this Cross of Reason exists is to combat the youths (ゆう) of the world, who just bring chaos into everything.

mnemonic: The tree has an umbrella, and it's holding it over his head, which is strange, because trees normally like water... turns out, it's not water falling on him, but dollar bills floating down.
on-yomi-mnemonic: The tree couldn’t take the body parts of his friends falling down on him, so he sat (さつ) down, and began crying uncontrollably.

mnemonic: The mouth clan are a group of people. They are the people of a nation.
on-yomi-mnemonic: The mouth clan peoples are a nation of people who use their mouths to say mean (みん) things to other peoples.

mnemonic: While riding your scooter, you take your sword and cut out an area on the ground. This whole place is your area now!
on-yomi-mnemonic: As you look down at your area, you suddenly realize there is a hen (へん) pecking at the ground in there. "Um, excuse me, hen, I believe I said this is MY area?!" You try to kick it out, but it hops over your leg.

mnemonic: You have to take the measurement of a leader. Imagine yourself measuring that leader's height and then coming up short. This is not good, you think. Leaders need to be at least six feet tall. So, to make the leader tall enough, you attach another head to the top of the leader's head.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: You have to remember the kun'yomi reading of this kanji, and the part you need to remember is つ. So, think of attaching something to something else. What would you need? You'd need two (つ) things to put together!

mnemonic: The lion drops a drop of saliva onto this person from above. The person is in a much worse place compared with where they were before, since they only just recently fell into this pit.
on-yomi-mnemonic: From above there is a loud caw, and a giant eagle (い) swoops down, forcing the lion to back off. The eagle grabs the person with its talons, bringing him into the air! But now he's... in the air being carried by a giant eagle, compared with where he was before, is this really better?!

mnemonic: Imagine looking out the window of your house and watching your husband slide down his slide over and over. He's not even good at it, he falls off the side halfway down most of the time. You want to complain, but he's pretty decent otherwise. This is his only fault.
on-yomi-mnemonic: You try to come up with another fault of his so you can complain when you see a tiny shih tzu (しつ) trotting by. Oh no! Before you can call out, your husband has fallen off the slide and crushed the poor thing. You hear a sharp yelp and then nothing.

mnemonic: The slide coming out of the patient's heart is there because a mad scientist is testing to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive now... but they are definitely slated for certain death.
on-yomi-mnemonic: As the beeping heart thing starts to do one long continuous beeeeeeeeeeeeeep, the doctor puts his hands together and hits (ひつ) the dead patient over and over, attempting to bring him back.

mnemonic: You're flying in a Jet. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, "Are we there yet? Are we there yet?" You have to keep responding. "Not yet! Not yet! NOT YET!"
on-yomi-mnemonic: What a selfish kid, right? Well, all he thinks about is "Me (み) me me me me me me me me me me." Hate kids like that.

mnemonic: This kanji uses a modified jet radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the end of the earth.
on-yomi-mnemonic: When you get to the end of the world, you land your jet and put out a few mats (まつ) to sit on so you can view the sights.

mnemonic: Next to the tree, a lid is put on your father. "Hello child," he says. "This is your new school."
on-yomi-mnemonic: our new school has other students too. They are all こういちs, though.

mnemonic: The eye leaf grows only in the winter. Every other leaf, however, will do the opposite, which is to grow in the summer.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: Now it's summertime! What do you do during the summer? You just sit around with your favorite string tying knots (なつ) in it over and over again.

mnemonic: Under this roof is a pig. Your pig, because it's your house! You keep your pig inside where it's nice and warm. He's a member of your family, so he deserves to live in your home too.
on-yomi-mnemonic: Also in your house, is your car (か). Your pig and your car are safe under your roof.

mnemonic: You have two bows but they're both covered in ice. This has made them very weak.
on-yomi-mnemonic: You give up on your trip and bring the weak bows back to your car, but it's stuck in the ice and snow. You decide to use the bows as a jack (じゃく) to try to get your car unstuck. Unfortunately, they're just too weak and they break in half.

mnemonic:
The sun is used in a temple to tell time. They don't have clocks or cell phones, they have sun dials and good old fashioned "looking up and seeing where the sun is right now."
This also can mean o' clock, as in "five o'clock" It's used when measuring what time it is in Japanese.
on-yomi-mnemonic: Time in a temple makes you think of Jesus (じ). Specifically, Jesus being able to perform time travel magic. He winks at you, goes back to the dinosaur ages, where he wrestles a T-rex. Then, he goes to WWII era and punches Hitler in the mouth.

mnemonic: The thread that ties you to your clan is paper. Your papers, that is.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: You need this specific paper to prove that you aren't a Commi (かみ), aka a Communist. Or that you are. It really depends on where you want to go and what decade this is.

mnemonic:
What you say to oneself (yourself), you decide to write down. Whether this is in the form of a journal, diary, or blog, you feel the need to record these important thoughts in some way.
Just imagine writing in a diary and saying everything to write aloud to yourself in your head.
on-yomi-mnemonic: You need to protect what you write down and record for yourself with a key (き). These are your special thoughts and feelings, you don't want anyone else to see! Lock them away with a key!

mnemonic: There's a scooter with your mama carrying a task she needs to get done. You see her pass through, hurrying by to get that task done.
on-yomi-mnemonic: As you watch your mama pass through the house, she yells, "YOU HAVE TO DO THIS TASK TOO (つう)!" Too?! Oh no, now you have to do it too. Hurry up!

mnemonic: There's a lid on your mouth and mustache, covering up all your talking holes. This is because you kept saying how tall and expensive you are.
on-yomi-mnemonic:
"I am taller and more expensive than you."
You're saying this because there are some こういちs in the room, and you want to make them feel inferior (you're a こういち hater).

mnemonic: You have a private bow made of insects that's extremely strong. Insect bodies are really durable, so they make for strong bows. You also have to be strong to use it, since it was made just for strong arms.
on-yomi-mnemonic: You had this strong bow made especially for you in きょうと. きょうと is famous for their strong bows, so if you ever want another, you know where to go.

mnemonic: A teacher in winter is happiest because they get to teach! The kids can't go out and play because it's too cold. They all have to come in and stay warm as the teacher teaches!
on-yomi-mnemonic: Teachers can teach the most about Japan in winter by going to きょうと. きょうと is where all the old temples and history of Japan is centered. And it's really gorgeous when it snows.

mnemonic: The king's village is the reason he's king. Without the village there would be no reason to have a king in the first place.
on-yomi-mnemonic: You can't have reason without re (り).

mnemonic: Picture a group of people threaded together by their top hats. Don't you want to be part of a cool group like that? Your own top hat team.
on-yomi-mnemonic: This group decides to make soap (そ) together. You take off your top hats and use them as soap molds, mixing together all of your favorite smells and colors.

mnemonic: Your boat has fins and a mouth! It's still a boat though.
on-yomi-mnemonic: This boat belongs to the centaurs (せん). That's probably why you've never seen a boat like it before.

mnemonic: Use a scooter to travel the circumference of the world and it will take you a full week. Seven whole days!
on-yomi-mnemonic: If you want to scoot for a week, you'll need shoes (しゅう). Good shoes too, not sandals or high heels or boots. Solid, high quality shoes, so you don't fall off the scooter and hurt yourself.

mnemonic: The rain is hated so much by wolverines, so they always want to live in the snow.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: You ask the wolverine, "Why do you want this snow so bad?" He replies quickly: "Because the rain is yucky" (ゆき).

mnemonic: The radical fish and the kanji fish are exactly the same!
on-yomi-mnemonic: You catch a fish. As you pull it out of the water, it starts yelling and pointing: "GO!" (ぎょ). "GO GYO GYO GYO!"

mnemonic: The radical bird and the kanji fish are exactly the same!
on-yomi-mnemonic: Think of a run of the mill bird, whatever comes to mind for you first is fine. Then, your lovely bird swells. The shape of a face, then a hand, start stretching the bird apart until it explodes outward. Covered in blood and feathers is Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

mnemonic: The radical yellow and the kanji yellow are exactly the same!
kun-yomi-mnemonic: You're in a room, surrounded completely by yellow. You can't get out. Somewhere in the room is a yellow key (き) but you can't find it, because everything looks the same. You crawl around trying to find this tiny thing so that you can escape.

mnemonic: The radical black and the kanji black are exactly the same!
on-yomi-mnemonic: You're in a completely black room. There's no way out, and you can't see. The room starts to fill with liquid. It gets in your mouth. You taste it. It's Coke (こく)! Mm, tasty Coke

mnemonic: There is an insect sliding around under your table, being blown by the wind. You try to grab the insect but it keeps sliding past your hand because the wind is so strong. It’s going to start blowing you around under the table too!
on-yomi-mnemonic: The only way you can distract yourself from the wind and the insect sliding around under your table is by eating lots of food (ふう).

mnemonic: その means "that" or "the", and その plus other means things like the others, other, and other than that, depending on the context.
reading-mnemonic: This has two readings, but luckily you learned one of them when you learned the kanji, and the other one when you learned the word 他. The two readings are usually interchangeable, too.

mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fix so the verb version is similar to that, to be fixed. This word is for when something is fixed, but you're not the one fixing it.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: Something needs to be fixed. It's urgent! You have to fix it now! (なお)
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: The ocean king's star is Neptune! If you know anything about Roman mythology this should be easy to remember!
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

mnemonic: If you exit somewhere in order to go to your company, that's going to the office, arriving at the office, and coming to work.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the しゅつ, which gets changed to しゅっ, as many つs do in this situation.

mnemonic: The fire star is Mars. This should be easy to remember, because Mars is the only planet in our solar system that's the color of fire.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

mnemonic: The tree star is the planet Jupiter. Imagine Jupiter covered in very strange trees — the kind that are able to take root in gas! It's a pretty weird image, but will hopefully help you to remember this word. Alternatively, think about how the clouds around Jupiter make patterns that look a lot like wood grain.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

mnemonic:
A person's hometown is a human habitation, or a village. This word has a slightly old-fashioned feel, and it's usually used for small villages in the countryside.
It's often combined with はなれた (separated) to talk about how far away from the nearest human habitation something is.
reading-mnemonic: This jukugo uses the kun'yomi of the kanji instead of the more usual on'yomi. You learned both of these readings when you learned the vocabulary 人 and 里. Just notice that さと becomes ざと, because of rendaku.

mnemonic: What's part of an hour? A minute, or minutes! This word is the suffix version of 分, so it goes after numbers to say how many minutes, and is used for telling the time too.
reading-mnemonic:
How many minutes of fun (ふん) will you have today? Lots and lots of minutes, I hope!
Depending on the number before 分, its pronunciation can change to ぷん, because of rendaku. We're looking for the original reading ふん here though!

mnemonic: Adding "third generation" to someone's name means that they are the third generation of people with that name. In this case, the person's name is ナポレオン (Napoleon), so this means Napoleon The Third, also written as Napoleon III.
reading: なぽれおんさんせい,ナポレオンさんせい
reading-mnemonic: The kanji here are pronounced exactly the same as in the standalone word 三世. That is, it's a jukugo word which uses the on'yomi for both kanji.

mnemonic: This word starts with an お to make it more polite. Then it has the kanji 兄 which you already know. Lastly, it has さん which is an honorific to elevate people and be polite. This is basically the formal way of saying older brother (versus plain old 兄). It can also be used to refer to a guy that you don't know who has a youthful appearance.
reading-mnemonic:
The reading for this one is pretty tricky, and I'd consider it an exception. To remember it, you have to learn the 兄 part, and everything else will fall into place. Here's a mnemonic to help you:
Your (kind) older brother pushes you down on the ground. You stand up and look at your knee (にい), which is all bloody. "Why'd you do that to my knee!?" you ask. "You're supposed to be a nice older brother, that's why I call you お兄さん!"

mnemonic: This is a noun version of think. What is "a think"? It's a thought.
reading-mnemonic: You learned this reading with 考える, just cut off the る!

mnemonic: The think way is really the way someone thinks. That's why this word means way of thinking.
reading-mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: You really want to eat food that's in neat shapes, so you decide to use a cutter (かた) on your cheese (ち) to make it a new shape. Square cheese is so boring. After you cut it up you have mouse shaped cheese! It just tastes better like that.
reading-mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading

mnemonic: You have a lack of points. These are things about yourself you wish were better. These are your shortcomings.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because けつ is being shortened to けっ here!

mnemonic: The kanji means family name because it goes after a family name in very formal situations. So, it's really closely tied to that. Because only men got the respect back in the day, we're calling this vocab word mister. You can call me Mr. Koichi if you'd like, too.
reading-mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji.

mnemonic: Both of these kanji have to do with names. You have both family name and name. Both of those names together makes for a First And Last Name... a full name if you will.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: When you have self reason, you are able to think for yourself. When you can think for yourself, you have freedom. Very philosophical this vocab is.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: The reason reason is so reason-ish! That's why this word means reason as well, how could it not? Do you have a reason why it shouldn't be? I thought not.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. When you see this word after a number, it’s for physical bills of money.
reading-mnemonic:
This is a suffix that takes the on’yomi reading, which you’ve learned already!
You'll also see this pronounced ふだ, but that's when it's a standalone word or part of a compound, rather than a suffix. So if you answer with that reading, you'll be prompted to enter the suffix reading instead.

mnemonic: The country peoples are the people of your country. They are the people.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji for area. This makes it have the same meaning as the kanji: area, vicinity, or neighborhood.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: If you think about an area that you're in, it's the place you're at (あた).
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: この means "this" so この辺 just means this area.
reading-mnemonic: The reading for the kanji portion is just what you've already learned with the kanji 辺 so this shouldn't be a difficult one to read for you.

mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attach so the verb version is to attach something.
reading-mnemonic: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this one just fine.

mnemonic: Compared with this, it's outside what you wanted. You'll have anything other than that.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: Compared with this, it's more. That's another way to say that what you have is more than it. That's all. ;)
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: From before, just means previously or before now.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic:
The kanji portion means fault, so you would think the verb version is "to fault." It's a little different, though. Think of it this way, if you "fault" something, you're messing up. What's a great way to mess up? By losing something. That's why this word means to lose.
Pretend like you are supposed to hold on to someone's wedding ring. You make the biggest fault of all. You lose it. Ouch.
reading-mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.
So how did you lose the wedding ring anyway? Well... it was eaten by a cow. The 牛 now (``c``) has to have it surgically removed. What a mess!

mnemonic: Your inside ポケット is your inside pocket.
reading: うちぽけっと, うちポケット
reading-mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for the kanji. You learned that reading when you learned the word 内.

word-type: Noun, する Verb, な Adjective
mnemonic:
When you do something that's your fault and then you say "thanks" after you do it, that's super-duper rude, wouldn't you say? Imagine doing something like this and then thinking to yourself after... wow, I was really rude.
This is also often used to mean excuse me, in which case it's usually followed by ですが or します. In casual situations, though, it's sometimes used on its own.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: This word looks like a verb but it's not (sorry!). It's an adverb. The kanji itself means certain and the vocab version means all sorts of variations on that: surely, certainly, and without exception to name a few.
kun-yomi-mnemonic:
Ra, the Egyptian god asks you: "Can you do it? Are you certain you can build the pyramids?"
"Yes I can ra (かなら). Yes I can," you reply.
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic:
Your future consists of certain death. How would you feel in this situation? Probably very frantic and desperate.
Another translation for this word is simply certain death, though I'd rather you learn one of the first two before this one if you can.
reading-mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi readings, though 必 (ひつ) gets shortened to ひっ. In your desperate situation just imagine that you're trying to get out of it, and to do so you move the つ only to find a smaller っ blocking your way. It is certain death.

mnemonic: This is the adverb version of 未, meaning it means the same thing: not yet.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: Someone's telling you "not yet... not yet.... not yet..." you have some food on your nose, but you're not allowed to eat it until your ma says it's okay. "Not yet... Not yet..." Why would your mom treat you like a dog like this? Oh well... maybe she'll let you eat the food soon, at least.
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: What has not yet come? The future.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: he kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Throw a "the" in there if you'd like, as well.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: You've reached the end of the universe. Nothing is there. You step out, and you're surprised because you get greeted by an old Canadian man. Sue, eh?(すえ) he asks you, over and over. The poor man is looking for his wife Sue, and he's searched to the end of the universe. That's true love. As he walks off into the distance, you hear him calling out "Sue, eh? Sue, eh? Sue, eh?"
reading-mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: The year end is the year end aka the end of the year.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: You know how 月 can also mean month? If you add 末 on there you have the "month end" aka the end of the month.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: The tall school is for when your kids get about as tall as they're going to get. That's high school, when most people stop growing taller.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: A study school is obviously a place where people study and learn. In English, that's simply a school.
reading-mnemonic: This jukugo word consists of on'yomi readings, except 学 (がく) is shortened with a small っ to make it がっこう.

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for the vocab.

mnemonic: You know that 夏 means summer and 休 means rest. What is a "summer rest" though? It's a summer break or summer vacation.
reading-mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi readings because this word is essentially two separate words put together into one word. You should know the reading for 夏 from the kanji and the reading for 休み from the vocab.

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: What do you do in your home? You eat eggs (いえ), that's what. You eat eggs three times a day, every day. You really love eating eggs in your house!
reading-mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: Think of it this way: An author makes (writes and creates works) in their home. Authors don't make their word magic in a corporate office!
reading-mnemonic: The readings are on'yomi readings, though さく from 作 gets shortened to さっ. Just be sure to remember that and you should be able to read this word just fine.

mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of weak? It's also weak.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: You just got beaten up because you're weak. Then the bully asks you: "Yo! Why (よわ) you so weak?"
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: he weak point is your weak point.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: What time is it? It's time to key (とき) your enemy's car. Imagine yourself looking at your watch, waiting until the correct time to perform a synchronized keying of someone's car. Who do you hate the most? Whose car would you like to key?
reading-mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: When it's one o'clock it's one o'clock. It's time to eat lunch, or take a nap, or something.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: When it's two o'clock and a half what time do you think it is? That would be two thirty.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

mnemonic: This is a good word to know to ask for the time. What is the time? This is how you ask what time it is.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: The same time? Okay, let's say what we think this word means at the same time. Whoops, I just said it, sorry.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but lucky for you that's the reading you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this vocab too.

mnemonic:
A hand paper is a letter because letters are generally written by hand on paper.
If you want a more graphic image, imagine writing a letter on your hand, and how much it would hurt to chop off your hand and send it.
reading-mnemonic: The reading is double kun'yomi (body parts tend to make kanji in words change to a kun'yomi reading). Both kanji in this word had you learn that reading right from the start, though, so you should be able to read this word. Just watch out for the rendaku making it がみ, not かみ.

mnemonic: When you write down your day (and do it every day) that's your diary.
reading-mnemonic: This jukugo word uses the on'yomi readings, except the 日 (にち) is shortened with a small っ, making the reading にっき.

mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pass through so the verb vocab version means things like to pass through, to pass, to travel along, and to stop by.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: There's something in front of you that you have to pass through but you can't. It's a wall. In order to pass through it, you decide to kick it as hard as you can to knock it down. Unfortunately, it is way stronger than you, and your toe explodes on contact. You yell: "TOE! OH!" (とお) and then just scream a lot.
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: Even though it gets mixed up as it passes through itself, modern traffic and transport systems are pretty amazing. This word refers to traffic and transport for pedestrians, bikes, cars, buses, trains, planes... anything that gets us from A to B.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of tall or expensive? It's the same: tall or expensive.
Weird that this word means both of these things, yeah? Just imagine money piled up to be really tall. That money is tall because it needs to buy something expensive.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: There's a tall dude trying to sell you something really expensive. He's really going off on how great this item is and how you should buy it. This guy is a real salesman. A real talker (たか).
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strong? It's also strong.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: So you wanna be strong huh? Well, all you have to do is eat these two yogurts (つよ). One is filled with horse steroids, the other is full of bull steroids. They will make you so strong.
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: You have strong power. This is your strength.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means teach so the verb vocab version means to teach. It's also used to mean to tell in a more general sense.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: Think about your favorite teacher. Now think about them teaching you the following: "Today I'm going to teach you about the ocean (おし)." It is big. Really big. Inside it are krakens, space aliens, and lost cities.
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: The teaching room is just a classroom.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: The reason your heart does what it does is all psychological. The study of that is psychology.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: The reason the earth is the way it is because of the geography of it. Though it may seem kind of strange that geography is bringing reason to the earth, if you think of geography as a study, then you can think about how you try to get reason through that, as well.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
kun-yomi-mnemonic:
You're part of a special group. It is the cumin group, and they deal with all things cumin (the spice / seed). Smell the cumin. Touch it. Taste it. You live and breathe the stuff, because you are the president of this cumin group.
P.S. This can also be spelled 組み (same overall reading: くみ).
reading-mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: You're riding in a boat. It's great. Imagine it being the best time you've had in your life. You tell everyone: "This is fun, eh?" (ふね). You're on a Canadian ship, which is why you add the "eh" in there. Say this out loud wherever you are right now while imagining the sea smell, the wind, and the excitement of boats.
reading-mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: A wind boat. This is a strange one for sure. You may assume this is like one of those giant balloons you can go ride around in, and you'd be partly right. Really, this word covers the general word balloon, though it especially has to do with the toy-style balloons (or smaller balloons). It's a little round wind ship!
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji

mnemonic: The previous week was last week.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji

mnemonic: The now week is this week.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji

mnemonic: The end of the week is the weekend... that is, unless you work on the weekend, but we can't cater to everyone here.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for this vocab word. Enjoy the snow!

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: Imagine a fish. Now imagine the fish playing soccer, while wearing a nun's outfit. This is a soccer nun (さかな).
reading-mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: A gold fish is really just gold in color, but it's still called a goldfish.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: An ocean fish is simply an ocean fish. They also happen to be the most delicious kind of fish.
reading: かいぎょ, うみざかな
reading-mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.
Note. it can be read using kun'yomi as well

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: When you think about birds, what is the most common bird you can think of? What bird do you hate the most or like eating the most? Either one will work. Now, imagine yourself going up to that bird. You did something terrible. You tore (とり) off its wing and started eating it
reading-mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: There are many white birds out there, for sure, but one really stands out if you ask me. That bird is the swan. It's big, it's white, and it's majestic.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: The yellow color is just yellow
reading-mnemonic: The readings are the same as the readings you learned with the kanji meaning you should be able to read this word right off the bat.

mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of black? It's also black. Special Note: The noun version of black also exists in Japanese. It is just 黒 with the same pronunciation, but minus the い which makes it adjective-tastic.
kun-yomi-mnemonic: Think of black things. One very common black thing is the common crow (くろ). Associate those two together.
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: A black person is simply a black person, kind of like how a 白人 is a "white person," but a different color.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: Something that is person shaped that isn't a person? That has to be some kind of doll or puppet.
reading-mnemonic: The reading for 人 is pretty normal, though the reading for 形 is different from the one you learned. To remember this, think of a doll... made totally of gyoza (ぎょう) dumplings. This doll is crazy (like most dolls) and it's eating itself and trying to get you to eat some of it too. Hey... why you no eat me? Mmmm. Gyoza doll.

mnemonic: When something is hand made, it is handmade!
reading-mnemonic: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. Just think of this word as two separate words put together (手 and 作る). The る in 作る gets changed to り because it's an adjective, and the つ in つくり gets changed to づ because of the way the words are combined with each other. You should know most of the reading that is in this word, though it will probably take a little bit of thinking to sort out the little changes in those readings.

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-mnemonic: Do you know the word "kamikaze" from WWII history? Well, it means "divine wind." The "kaze" part is the wind part, and this word uses the same reading, making it かぜ as well.

mnemonic: You know that 学生 means "student" and you know that 大学 means university/college. Combine the two and you have a university student / college student.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: The way of saying something is your way of saying. This could be your accent or simply the way you talk.
reading-mnemonic: You've seen 言う. Let's steal that word's reading. And, you already know 方 and its reading. Combine those together and you have the reading for this word.

mnemonic: If you get there previous to something rotating (回り), you are arriving ahead, or going ahead in anticipation.
reading-mnemonic: This consists of a couple kun'yomi readings put together. You can tell it's kun'yomi because of the hiragana sticking out at the end. In previous levels, you learned both the words 先 and 回る (verb version of 回り). If you know those, you should be able to put them together to learn the reading of this word as well.

mnemonic: When something is close close (the 々 character repeats the kanji that was before it) it will happen before long.
reading-mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading twice; that's the one you learn with the vocab word 近い from the previous level. The second 近 gets converted to ぢか, though, so take note of that.

mnemonic: This is simply a blue sky (aka a blue sky!).
reading-mnemonic:
You'd think that this word would use on'yomi readings to read it, but it doesn't (shake that angry fist at the kanji gods!). Instead, it's double kun'yomi, probably because this word is really like two separate words put together.
One quick note is the rendaku-fication of 空 as well. It becomes ぞら

mnemonic: You know 学生 is student, so what is a small student? Think young. That would be an Elementary School Student.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: This is the way to make something. This is how to make something. You'll see this for directions on building something.
reading-mnemonic: You should know the kun'yomi readings for both of these from lower level vocab. Use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

mnemonic: You've seen 学生 (means student). Now let's look at a student who's in the middle. Perhaps we can call this a middle school student or a junior high school student, depending on where you're from
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: You already know 人気 which means "popular." And you also know that 不 means "not." So what do you get when you combine the two? Something that's not popular or unpopular.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: The reasoning of your heart decides what you do. Probably when kanji was being made people thought that the heart directed our actions, not our brains. So, if you think about it that way, the reasoning of your heart is your mental state. Nowadays that's known as psychology.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: You have a period of time and it's called a period or era! Simple!
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: 本当 is reality or truth (level 5 vocab). If you add on に, this changes the word to an adverb, and we get really or truly. 本当に!
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It shares the reading with the level 5 本当 as well, but just has a particle on the end. Really!

mnemonic: Not to be confused with 会社, which is a company, this is society. When a company meets together, it's like a bunch of people, who are in groups, who come together to live in one world. That is a society.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

mnemonic: A street you can see with your eye isn't soooo big you can't see it (like a town would be), but it's still pretty big because it has a street. This section of the town is the district of a town, or a city block (though specifically one of an irregular size).
reading-mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, so use those and you'll be A-Okay.

mnemonic: If there's a number before 時, it means o'clock. For example １時 is 1:00, and ２３時 is 23:00 or 11pm.
reading-mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji big. It's a little thing you can put in front of things to say that they are "in a big way" or "on a grand scale."
reading-mnemonic: Since you already know the reading of the vocab word 大きい, you should be able to read this word as well.

mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji near. So it also means near, or in the neighborhood of something.
reading-mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 近い, so you should be able to read this word as well.

mnemonic: A machine that pumps wind can malfunction and make too much, causing a typhoon. It's a really powerful machine to be able to move that much wind.
reading-mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Instead of だい for 台 though, this uses the reading たい.
When a typhoon is coming you have to tie (たい) down all of your stuff. Or, you know, if you already know the word typhoon, that's fine too.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

mnemonic: This is a counter that can be used after numbers to let you know what number room it is. It's a room number that you use in apartments and hotels to know exactly which room you're looking for.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

mnemonic: The big thing in the sky is the heavens. The heavens where birds and planes soar, not the one you go to after you die if you've been really good.
reading-mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that そら becomes ぞら because of rendaku here.

mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. It's made up of the kanji for see and right, so what happens when you see the right thing? You manage to come upon what you're looking for or to be found, if you're the one who's lost and you see the right people that are looking for you.
Note: This verb is almost always used in the negative form. It is very, very rare for it to be positive. So when you're using it, make sure no one found the thing you're talking about!
reading-mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings.

mnemonic: You already learned that 三角 means "triangle." Well this means triangle too, but it's the mathematical term. You should use it in math class.
reading: さんかくけい,さんかっけい
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

mnemonic: You know that 活用 means "conjugation" and that 〜形 means "form", so that means this is the conjugated form!
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

mnemonic: Okay, so this one is really weird, sorry. Each of us only get one body in our lifetimes, right? Well what the heck! What if I want more than one body. Let's all be mad about this together.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

mnemonic: A small voice is so small that you can hardly hear it. It's a low voice or a whisper.
reading-mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because, like in 大声, the こえ becomes ごえ thanks to our old friend rendaku.

mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

mnemonic: Compared with this, it's below. That's another way to say that what you have is less than it.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

mnemonic: Town peoples are the townspeople!
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

mnemonic: The next week is the next week. It isn't last week or this week, it's the next one!
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sunlight, so the verb is to shine or to glitter. Just imagine what happens when sunlight hits things!
reading-mnemonic: Remember how you learned the reading for 光? Well this is almost the same thing. Just change the り to る and you'll know this reading!

mnemonic: This word is almost the same as the kanji, but only half of it. It means tag or amulet. They're about the same shape and size as money, but you can't buy a house with them (...probably).
kun-yomi-mnemonic: You can't find your tag anywhere. It was just there, you swear, but now it's nowhere to be found. You search for it everywhere, then you realize... it was right there all along. Seriously? You're such a fool, duh (ふだ)!
reading-mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading.

mnemonic: From after, just means after this or from now on.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.

mnemonic: One bread loaf counter is counting one loaf of bread.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening though!

mnemonic: Two bread loaf counters are counting two loaves of bread.
reading-mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
